message.raw:
Do not use importlib_metadata to inspect its own version initially,
this is circular logic. Just trust importlib_metadata.__version__, then
follow up with a full check only if that is high enough.

this is circular logic. Just trust importlib_metadata.version, then

message.raw:
Add two new functions get_attributes and set_attributes, for getting and setting
attributes with the automatic JSON serialisation/deserialisation on arbitrary
HDF5 groups, not just device groups. This is basically just exposing the same
functionality as the get/set device properties functions, but allowing you
to specify the HDF5 group instead of the device name.

This can be used by BLACS workers and by the lyse API to enable saving
acquisition metadata and analysis results that are more complex datatypes.

This is motivated by [labscript devices pull request #71](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/71)
which is a camera device that would like to save nested dictionaries as
attributes.

Minor version bump so other code can rely on this.

message.raw:
Have processes delay terminating until after they have closed HDF5 files.
This can prevent data corruption and ensure zlocks are released when
the process is terminated.

This may not play well with any processes that hold the HDF5 file open for
long periods of times, but such processes should be changed to be more polite.

message.raw:
Add function fix_shortcuts() to winshell, and have it run if winshell is run
as main with:

python -m labscript_utils.winshell --fix-shortcuts

This function will re-make labscript suite application shortcuts and start menu
entries. This can fix broken shortcuts in the case that old shortcuts were from
before winshell could make shortcuts interact well with newer versions of conda.

Catch DLL load error upon importing Qt in the splash submodule, and raise
an exception advising that the user might try running the above command to fix
their shortcuts, since this DLL load error is the first one to be hit in the
applications when they are launched from incorrect shortcuts.
message.html:
Add function fix_shortcuts() to winshell, and have it run if winshell is run
as main with:

python -m labscript_utils.winshell --fix-shortcuts

This function will re-make labscript suite application shortcuts and start menu
entries. This can fix broken shortcuts in the case that old shortcuts were from
before winshell could make shortcuts interact well with newer versions of conda.

Catch DLL load error upon importing Qt in the splash submodule, and raise
an exception advising that the user might try running the above command to fix
their shortcuts, since this DLL load error is the first one to be hit in the
applications when they are launched from incorrect shortcuts.

Only tell launcher to initialise conda env if both required environment
variables are present. This way apps running under cwp.py will not break
(well, they may remain equally as broken as they are now, but they will not
crash at startup because they can't find environment variables)

message.raw:
Move functionality from the installer into winshell module for consistent
app descriptions (app descriptions in the taskbar vs start menu differed
previously), and to allow apps to know at run time what the command
to launch them is, since they need to set it as their relaunch command.

Add launcher that runs apps in a conda environment, and that if run with pythonw
runs apps in python.exe without a console window. This solves a number of issues
relating to pythonw and makes zprocess's output redirection more comprehensive.
For example, C/cython extensions or non-python subprocess output cannot be
redirected to output boxes when running under pythonw. Starting the launcher
with pythonw.exe and then having it run the target with python.exe allows for
no console window to be visible, even for a moment.

Using this launcher instead of cwp.py from the menuinst project is also required
because our apps need more environment variables pertaining to conda than are
set by cwp.py. Further, cwp.py unconditionally sets the working directory
to the user's documents directory, whereas we have configured out own working
directories that we would prefer our apps to run in.

value was being interpreted as True, i.e. the server/client were being started
with --allow_insecure even if allow_insecure=False in the labconfig file.
Use labconfig.getint for other properties while I'm at it.

create additional log files with unrelated filepaths on the computer running
the top-level process.

message.raw:
Post-filter before_get method of default interpolation instead of overriding it.

Environment variables specified with % symbols need to be escaped, e.g.
  [programs]
  text_editor = %%PROGRAMFILES%%\Sublime Text 3\sublime_text.exe
  text_editor_arguments = {file}
  hdf5_viewer = %%LOCALAPPDATA%%\HDF_Group\HDFView\3.1.0\hdfview.bat
  hdf5_viewer_arguments = {file}

message.raw:
Expand environment variables in labconfig using configparser.BasicInterpolation.
Requires using the backport of configparser for Python 2. Replaced all instances
of SafeConfigParser class as it has been renamed to ConfigParser.

Example usage in labconfig on Windows:
  [programs]
  text_editor = %PROGRAMFILES%\Sublime Text 3\sublime_text.exe
  text_editor_arguments = {file}
  hdf5_viewer = %LOCALAPPDATA%\HDF_Group\HDFView\3.1.0\hdfview.bat
  hdf5_viewer_arguments = {file}
message.html:
Expand environment variables in labconfig using configparser.BasicInterpolation.
Requires using the backport of configparser for Python 2. Replaced all instances
of SafeConfigParser class as it has been renamed to ConfigParser.

Example usage in labconfig on Windows:
[programs]
text_editor = %PROGRAMFILES%\Sublime Text 3\sublime_text.exe
text_editor_arguments = {file}
hdf5_viewer = %LOCALAPPDATA%\HDF_Group\HDFView\3.1.0\hdfview.bat
hdf5_viewer_arguments = {file}

message.raw:
Allow serialiser to serialise bytestings, by base64 encoding them with a prefix.

JSON does not distinguish between bytestrings and unicode strings, but Python
does, and Python 3 has stricter requirements not to confuse the two.

In order for a bytestrings to survive serialisation and deserialisation, this
change encodes bytestrings as base64, adds a prefix, and the result is serialised
in the JSON ouput the same as any unicode string. Upon deserialisation, strings
are inspected for the prefix and decoded.

This is motivated by the labscript driver for NI IMAQdx cameras. Camera attributes
can be set, which are currently stored as connection table properties or device
properties. Currently they are stored as strings, even though this leads to
various issues with the Python nivision API choking on some of them since they
are not the right datatype. Not only can attributes be strings or integers or floats
etc, but nivision makes a distinction between byestrings and unicode strings.
So to correctly set these, our serialisation needs to allow this distinction to
round-trip.

This encoding of bytestrings is only performed for Python 3. The NI IMAQdx camera
server is Python3-only in any case.

message.raw:
Do not require zprocess merely to disable quick edit.
Only disable quick edit if zprocess is importable and new enough, otherwise
ignore.

This is important so that we are not throwing version errors just because
someone imported labscript_utils, such as in the installer, where we would
like to print more friendly errors.

message.raw:
Move ensure_connected_to_zlog and connect_to_zlock into ls_zprocess.
Have Lock() ignore the read_only argument if the zlock server does not support
it. This way callers may use the argument without having to check first.
Have h5_lock pass the read_only keyword argument along, it will be ignored
later if it is not supported.

This was motivated by the runmanager sequence_id changes, which use a zlock Lock
to serialise access to the file that stores the current sequence index. This
way the runmanager code will work with old zlock servers.

Patch version bump so the runmanager changes can rely on this.
